{{news release|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Jebsen & Jessen Group of Companies South East Asia | logo = Jebsen & Jessen (SEA).jpg | type = Private | area_served = ASEAN, China, Australia, Taiwan | key_people = Heinrich Jessen <small>(Chairman)</small>, Per Magnusson <small> (Executive Vice Chairman)</small> | industry = Manufacturing, Engineering, Distribution | revenue = S$1.3 billion (2017)<ref>[http://www.jjsea/doc/aboutus.com Jebsen & Jessen website]</ref> | num_employees = 4,400 (2017)<ref>[http://www.jjsea/doc/aboutus.com Jebsen & Jessen website]</ref> | intl = | homepage = {{URL|www.jjsea.com}} | foundation = 1963 | location_city = [[Singapore]] }}
'''Jebsen & Jessen (SEA)''' is a diversified industrial group based in South East Asia. It is a third generation family-owned enterprise and part of the Jebsen & Jessen Family Enterprise.
== Company Information == Their main corporate office is headquartered in Singapore with regional business units headquartered in other ASEAN countries. The company generated over S$1.3 billion revenue in 2017, employs over 4,400 employees and has more than 50 subsidiaries and associate companies.
The company has a number of joint ventures including MHE-Demag (a joint venture with Demag Cranes and Components ), JJ-Lurgi Engineering (a joint venture with Air Liquide), JJ-Lapp Cable (a joint venture with Lapp Holding Asia), [https://www.jj-muntons.com/ JJ-Muntons]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foodnavigator-asia.com/Article/2016/06/17/JJ-Muntons-joint-venture-inaugurates-Chonburi-plant|title=JJ-Muntons joint-venture inaugurates Chonburi plant|work=foodnavigator-asia.com|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref> (a joint venture with Muntons), and JJ-Pun<ref name=":0" /> (a joint venture with Serge Pun & Associates Group).
In May 2011 company executives indicated that the company has an acquisition war chest of SGD 250 million to support its growth strategy.<ref>Lynn Kan,"Jebsen and Jessen on expansion path", "The Business Times", May 9, 2011</ref><ref>Staff Reporter, [http://sbr.com.sg/building-engineering/exclusive/jebsen-jessen-invests-s250-million-south-east-asia-expansion] "Jebsen & Jessen invests S$250 million for South East Asia expansion", "Singapore Business Review", 10 May 2011</ref>
== History == The group was established in 1963 in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and has its roots in [[Jebsen & Co]], a trading partnership formed in Hong Kong in 1895. Management positions are held today by descendants of the Jebsen & Co founders, Jacob Jebsen (1870–1941, [[:de:Jacob Jebsen|de]]) and Heinrich Jessen (1865–1931).
After incorporation in 1963, Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) operated in Singapore and Malaysia, and subsequently set up offices throughout South East Asia. By 1971 the company had more than 600 employees and was trading pharmaceuticals, engineering, photographic products, construction equipment and home appliances.
In the early 1970s the company acquired agencies for luxury watch brands, and also formed an agreement with Demag AG and set up mechanical handling engineering in 1972, trading and manufacturing hoists and cranes. In 1976 the company established Jebsen & Jessen Packaging.
In 1982 the group holding company Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) Pte Ltd was set up, its three departments included Engineering, Manufacturing and Trade & Industry. In 1986 MHE-Demag became a 50/50 joint venture between Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) and [[Demag]]. By the 25th anniversary in 1988, the Group had over 30 subsidiaries and employed 1,000 people.
On March 1, 1992, JJ-Lurgi was formed as a 50/50 joint venture between Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) and [[Lurgi AG]]. Current Chairman Heinrich Jessen joined the company as environment, health and safety manager in 1995.
In 2004 the group began a 50/50 joint venture with German Lapp Kable, forming JJ-Lapp Cable. The group obtained ISO 14001 and OHSAS certifications across its 40 subsidiaries in 2004.<ref>[http://www.jjsea.com/TheThreeMackerels/Index.html] "The Three Mackerels, The Story of the Jebsen and Jessen Family Enterprise"</ref>
In 2010, the group expanded their regional reach by opening an office in Cambodia.<ref>"Global family company opens in Cambodia", "Phnom Penh Post", 24 Feb 2011</ref> and in July 2011, it entered Myanmar with a 50/50 joint venture with family-owned Serge Pun & Associates Group (SPA Group), forming JJ-Pun (S) Pte Ltd.<ref name=":0">Soe Sandar Oo, [http://www.mmtimes.com/2011/business/584/biz58402.html], "SPA joins new joint venture", "Myanmar Times", 10 May 2011</ref>
The group announced its acquisition of Halcyon Offshore, a leading offshore and marine services company on May 28, 2012.<ref>Joyce Hooi,"Jebsen & Jessen ventures into marine, buys Halcyon Offshore", "The Business Times", May 30, 2012</ref><ref name=":1">Krisana Gallezo, [http://sbr.com.sg/shipping-marine/more-news/jebsen-jebsen-group-acquires-halcyon-offshore] "Jebsen & Jessen Group Acquires Halcyon Offshore", "Singapore Business Review", 29 May 2012</ref>
In March 2014, Jebsen & Jessen Ingredients made the move into manufacturing malted ingredients, signing a 50:50 joint venture agreement with UK firm Muntons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foodbev.com/news/jebsen-jessen-and-muntons-form-thailand/|title=FoodBev Media|last=Weston|first=Shaun|date=April 24, 2014|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
In January 2015, MHE-Demag acquired Demag Cranes & Components Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.liftandhoist.com/article/acquisition-enhances-demag%E2%80%99s-position-asia-pacific|title=Lift & Hoist International|last=|first=|date=2015-06-19|website=http://www.liftandhoist.com/|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ferret.com.au/c/demag-cranes-components/mhe-demag-to-acquire-sister-company-demag-cranes-components-n2523129|title=MHE-Demag to acquire sister company Demag Cranes & Components|website=www.ferret.com.au|access-date=2016-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vertikal.net/en/news/story/23066/|title=Terex sells Australian distributor {{!}} News {{!}} Vertikal.net|website=www.vertikal.net|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref>
In March 2015, JJ-Lapp Cable acquired 100% stake in PT JJ-Lapp Cable SM (JJSMI). This comes five years after JJ-Lapp Cable and PT Sinarmonas) entered a joint-venture relationship.
In October 2015, the group divested their Communications<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/dimension-data-completes-acquisition-jebsen-jessen-comms-unit|title=Dimension Data completes acquisition of Jebsen & Jessen comms unit|date=2016-02-04|work=Digital News Asia|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> and Healthcare divisions.<ref>[http://www.jjsea.com/PageDisplay.aspx?aid=2929658A-7046-4164-84BE-B1E74589DCB3&action=ShowNewsDetail&id=f469a3d0-56cd-4d3a-a1fb-6f063641d371] "Divesting into the Next Strategic Chapter"</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mymedicnews.com/industry-news/3571-getz-healthcare-acquires-jebsen-amp-jessen-healthcare-businesses-in-malaysia-amp-thailand/|title=Getz Healthcare Acquires Jebsen & Jessen Healthcare Businesses In Malaysia & Thailand - My Medic News|work=My Medic News|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref>
In June 2016, JJ-Muntons opened the new 3,000sqm specialty malted manufacturing facility in Chonburi, Thailand.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foodnavigator-asia.com/Article/2016/06/17/JJ-Muntons-joint-venture-inaugurates-Chonburi-plant|title=JJ-Muntons joint-venture inaugurates Chonburi plant|work=foodnavigator-asia.com|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In November 2016, MHE-Demag opened South East Asia's largest crane manufacturing plant in Malaysia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hoistmagazine.com/news/mhe-demag-opens-10m-manufacturing-plant-in-malaysia-5691715/|title=MHE-Demag opens $10m manufacturing plant in Malaysia - HOIST magazine|website=www.hoistmagazine.com|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref>
In January 2018, the group and sister company Jebsen Group in China announced the establishment of a joint venture of equals in Greater China between Jebsen & Jessen Ingredients (JJING) and Jebsen Industrial Specialty Ingredients & Solutions Business (JI-SI&S)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodingredientsfirst.com/news/jebsen-jessen-and-jebsen-group-form-jv-in-china.html|title=Jebsen & Jessen and Jebsen Group form JV in China|last=MEDIA|first=CNS|website=foodingredientsfirst.com/|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref>.
== Businesses == The group have seven core business units: Cable Technology, Ingredients, Life Sciences, Material Handling, Offshore, Packaging, and Technology.
=== Cable Technology === JJ-Lapp Cable specialises in manufacturing and distribution of cable and cable related products for the automotive manufacturing, building construction, building automation, component manufacturing, material handling, pulp & paper and other industries.
=== Ingredients === Jebsen & Jessen Ingredients distributes [[specialty chemicals]], including additives, fillers, pigments, resins, solvents, cross linker, flame retardants, monomers/polymers, and performance chemicals to manufacturing industries; amino acids and protein sources to animal feed manufacturers; food additives and ingredients for the treatment and flavoring of food and beverages; and chemicals for the pharma industries.
=== Life Sciences === JJ-Lurgi Engineering offers technologies and engineering services for oil seed extraction, natural oils and fats production, and edible oil and bio fuel processing.
=== Material Handling === MHE-Demag is a joint venture between Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) and Demag Cranes and Components GmbH. The company engineers, manufactures and services material handling products including cranes, hoists, explosion proof lifting equipment, warehouse trucks, dock levelers, rail systems, car park systems, electrification systems and building maintenance units.
=== Offshore === Jebsen & Jessen Offshore distributes offshore and marine cables under the brand Cables International. Formerly Halcyon Offshore<ref name=":1" />, the company joined Jebsen & Jessen (SEA) on June 21, 2012 as a new regional business unit within the group.
=== Packaging === Jebsen & Jessen Packaging manufactures and supplies foam, plastic, paper, wood and integrated packaging products as well as moulded foam components, engineered foam for construction and related design & engineering services.
=== Technology === Jebsen & Jessen Technology engages in the distribution of industrial and commercial pumps, motors, turf and irrigation management systems, dry bulk handling [[solution]] as well as equipment for transport, chemical, and precision engineering industries.
== Recognition == {| class="wikitable" |'''Year''' |'''Award''' |- |2016 |21st annual IMD-Lombard Odier Global Family Business Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imd.org/news/updates/IMD-Lombard-Odier-Global-Family-Business-Award-2016/|title=Asian-focused conglomerate Jebsen & Jessen Family Enterprise awarded the IMD-Lombard Odier Global Family Business Award|website=IMD business school|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> (Jebsen & Jessen Family Enterprise) |- |2016 |EY-Barclays Family Business Award of Excellence<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/hub/ey-entrepreneur-of-the-year-2016/keeping-the-family-spirit-alive|title=Keeping the family spirit alive|last=Kan|first=Francis|work=The Business Times|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> (Jebsen & Jessen South East Asia) |- |2017 |Singapore Business Award - 2016 Businessman of the Year<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/jebsen-jessen-boss-heinrich-jessen-is-businessman-of-the-year|title=Jebsen & Jessen boss Heinrich Jessen is Businessman of the Year|last=hermesauto|date=2017-04-25|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> (Heinrich Jessen) |- |2018 |SBR International Business Awards 2018 - Building Services & Facilities<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sbr.com.sg/co-written-partner/more-news/mhe-demag-bags-sbr-international-business-awards-building-services-and-|title=MHE-Demag bags SBR International Business Awards for Building Services and Facilities|work=Singapore Business Review|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> (MHE-Demag) |}

{{About|the American musician and arts advocate|the American athlete|Jen Toomey}} {{Infobox person | name = Jenny Toomey | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jennifer Gillen Toomey | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1968}} | birth_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | occupation = Musician
Arts activist | years_active = | website = {{URL|jennytoomey.com|JennyToomey.com}} }} '''Jennifer "Jenny" Gillen Toomey''' (born in 1968) is an [[United States|American]] [[indie rock]] musician and arts activist. == Early life and education == Toomey is from [[Chevy Chase, Maryland]], and later, [[Washington, D.C.]] Toomey is a graduate of [[Georgetown University]] with a degree in [[philosophy]]. == Career == Toomey was a member of the bands Geek, [[Tsunami (band)|Tsunami]], Liquorice, [[Grenadine (band)|Grenadine]], So Low and Choke, among others, and has also recorded under her own name.{{cite news|last1=Rapa|first1=Patrick|title=The Match: Indie rock mothers of invention Tsunami are still fighting the good fight and reuniting for Ladyfest|url=http://citypaper.net:80/articles/2003-03-20/cover9.shtml|work=[[Philadelphia City Paper]]|date=20 March 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030426001930/http://citypaper.net/articles/2003-03-20/cover9.shtml|archivedate=26 April 2003|deadurl=yes|df=}} In 1990, Toomey co-founded the [[Simple Machines]] record label with a housemate who left the project soon after. Toomey ran the label with [[Kristin Thomson]] from 1990 to 1998 out of their house in [[Arlington, Virginia]]. Along with [[TeenBeat Records]] and [[Dischord Records]], Simple Machines helped document the D.C. [[punk rock|punk]] and [[indie rock]] scenes. Tsunami was also greatly influential in the [[do it yourself|do it yourself (D.I.Y.)]] movement among the punk, grunge and indie communities. Among the artists released on Simple Machines are Tsunami, Grenadine, [[Franklin Bruno]], [[Ida (band)|Ida]], and [[Scrawl]], among others.{{cite web|title=Simple Machines Records: Story|url=http://www.simplemachines.net/story.html|website=[[Simple Machines]]}} In 2000, Toomey founded the [[Future of Music Coalition]], a Washington, D.C. [[think tank]] that translates the complex issues at the intersection of music, policy and law, aiming to help (primarily independent) musicians, including [[Intellectual property|intellectual property rights]], health insurance, and the effects of corporate consolidation of radio and the music industry. She was the founding executive director.{{cite news|last1=Ulaby|first1=Neda|title=Jenny Toomey, Rocking the FCC|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1644659|work=[[Morning Edition]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=11 February 2004|language=en|format=Includes audio}} As part of her advocacy work, Toomey participated in many conferences, including the Future of the Music Industry forum held at Georgetown University in January 2003, among others.{{cite news|last1=Adelstein|first1=Jonathan S.|last2=Lightfoot|first2=David|last3=Toomey|first3=Jenny|title=Music Industry Digital Technology|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?174441-1/music-industry-digital-technology|work=[[Georgetown University]], [[Future of Music Coalition]]|publisher=[[C-SPAN]]|date=6 January 2003|format=Video}} In November 2007, she was appointed Program Officer for Media and Cultural Policy in the Media, Arts and Culture Unit at the [[Ford Foundation]]. She is currently Director, Internet Freedom at the [[Ford Foundation]]. ==Discography== with '''Choke''' * ''Kingdom of Mattresses'' (1990) with '''Geek''' * ''Wedge (Various Artists)'' (1990) * ''Three's Company (Various Artists)'' (1990) * ''Screw (Various Artists)'' (1991) * ''Hammer'' with '''My New Boyfriend''' * ''Pulley (Various Artists)'' (1991) * ''Supersaw'' with '''Slack''' * ''Neapolitan Metropolitan (Various Artists)'' (1992) * ''Bates Stamper'' with '''Grenadine''' * ''Goya'' (1992) * ''Trilogy'' (1992) * ''Don't Forget the Halo'' (1993) * ''Nopalitos'' (1994) * ''Christiansen'' (1994) with '''Tsunami''' * ''Deep End'' (1993) * ''The Heart's Tremolo'' (1994) * ''World Tour and Other Destinations'' (1995) * ''A Brilliant Mistake'' (1997) with '''Liquorice''' * ''Stalls'' (1995) * ''Listening Cap'' (1995) ===Solo=== * ''Antidote'' (2001) * ''Tempting'' (2002) == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ;TO MAKE INLINE * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1644659 "Arts & Culture: Jenny Toomey, Rocking the FCC: Artist/Activist Seeks Local Radio Access for Independent Musicians"], from [[National Public Radio]] ''Morning Edition'' program, February 11, 2004 * [http://www.copacetic-zine.com/concerts/jennytoomey.php Jenny Toomey on copacetic] * [http://www.narm.com/events/2001%20Convention/naylor/Speaker_Bios/toomeyjenny_bio.htm Speaker Bio] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051204132248/http://citypaper.net/articles/2003-03-20/browse.shtml ''Ladyfest Philly rallies women in the arts to take over the town.''] * [http://www.copacetic-zine.com/concerts/bumbershoot2002.php Bumbershoot review] * [http://www.bandtoband.com/artist/jennifer-toomey Jennifer Toomey - BandToBand.com] == External links == * {{URL|jennytoomey.com|JennyToomey.com}} * {{Twitter}} * [https://www.fordfoundation.org/people/jenny-toomey/ Jenny Toomey] at the [[Ford Foundation]] * {{URL|futureofmusic.org|Future of Music Coalition}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toomey, Jenny}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American activists]] [[Category:American feminist writers]] [[Category:Copyright activists]] [[Category:American female musicians]] [[Category:Georgetown University alumni]]

{{Refimprove|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox organization | name = Legal Services NYC | logo = Legalservicesnyc.png | type = [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit]] | founded = 1967 | location = [[New York City]] | key_people = Raun Rasmussen, Executive Director<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legalservicesnyc.org/about-us/our-people/leadership-team |title=Executive Team |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= |publisher=Legal Services NYC |access-date= 19 October 2018}}</ref> | fields = [[Legal services]] to low-income New Yorkers | services = Legal services | homepage = {{official URL}} | motto = }}
'''Legal Services NYC''' ('''LSNYC''') is a [[nonprofit organization|non-profit organization]] that provides free [[civil law (common law)|civil]] [[legal services|legal assistance]] to low-income people in [[New York City]]. The community-based organization serves more than 100,000 clients annually.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legalservicesnyc.org/about-us |title=About Us |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= |publisher=Legal Services NYC |access-date= 19 October 2018}}</ref> It is the nation's largest organization exclusively devoted to providing free civil services to the poor, with programs located in low-income neighborhoods throughout New York City.
==History== In 1967, a group of federally funded [[legal services]] offices united to become Community Action for Legal Services (CALS), which later changed to Legal Services for New York City. After adopting a new logo<ref name="probono.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.probono.net/images/areas/333/LS%20NYC%20logo_Photo.jpg|format=JPG|title=Photographic image of logo|website=Probono.net\accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> and brand, the organization changed its name in 2007, on its 40th anniversary, to Legal Services NYC (LSNYC).<ref name="probono.net"/> The first landmark win for LSNYC came in 1970 with ''[[Goldberg v. Kelly]]'', where the [[Supreme Court of the United States|US Supreme Court]] laid down the [[due process]] standards for the termination of government benefits.
==Structure== The organization's structure serves [[New York City]]'s low-income community on the local level. Some of the local units are run from the central office, while others are independent organizations with their own local board of directors. Each borough has its own program: Manhattan Legal Services, Queens Legal Services, [[Staten Island Legal Services]], Bronx Legal Services, and Brooklyn Legal Services. There is also a citywide Central Office and a Legal Support Unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legalservicesnyc.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=46&Itemid=75|title=Our Program - Legal Services NYC|first=Kate|last=Whalen|website=Legalservicesnyc.org|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>
==Services== The organization represents clients in [[court]]s and [[administrative proceeding]]s. It also provides advice or referral information if unable to provide representation. Assistance is provided through legal education and community workshops, help lines and written materials. The organization also provides training to [[poverty law]] attorneys and advocates through its Legal Support Unit.
==Governance== LSNYC is governed by a board of directors; the members are appointed by Bar Associations, community groups, and other entities. The board of directors is led by the executive committee, composed of the Chair, Vice Chair, Treasurer and Secretary, and three additional non-officer members of the board.
==See also== {{Portal|Law|New York City}} * [[Legal Services Corporation]] * ''[[Pro bono]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website}} * [http://supreme.justia.com/us/397/254/case.html Goldberg v. Kelly 397 U.S. 254 (1970) text on Justia.com] * [http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=case&court=us&vol=397&page=254 Goldberg v. Kelly 397 U.S. 254 (1970) text on findlaw.com]

'''Metabolife International, Inc.,''' was a [[multi-level marketing]] company based in [[San Diego, California]] which manufactured [[dietary supplements]]. Metabolife's best-selling product, an [[ephedra|ephedra-based]] supplement called ''Metabolife 356'', once generated hundreds of millions of dollars in annual sales.<ref name="sdbj"/> However, Metabolife 356 and other ephedra-containing supplements were linked to thousands of [[serious adverse event]]s, including deaths, which caused the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) to ban the sale of ephedra-containing dietary supplements in 2004.
Subsequently, Metabolife's founder Michael Ellis was convicted of lying to the FDA and concealing evidence of ephedra's dangers, and the company and its owner were both convicted of [[income tax evasion]]. A congressional investigation found that Metabolife had received thousands of reports of serious adverse events, many occurring in young and otherwise healthy people, and that Metabolife concealed the reports and acted with "indifference to the health of consumers."<ref name="house-investigation">{{cite web | publisher = [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform]] | title = Adverse Event Reports from Metabolife | url = http://oversight-archive.waxman.house.gov/documents/20040827102309-56026.pdf | date = October 2002 | accessdate = 2013-03-29 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141223212556/http://oversight-archive.waxman.house.gov/documents/20040827102309-56026.pdf | archivedate = 2014-12-23 | df = }}</ref>
== History == Metabolife was founded in the early 1990s by Michael Ellis, a former [[police officer]] on [[probation]] for charges relating to his involvement with a [[methamphetamine]] lab.<ref name="salon">{{cite news |publisher = [[Salon.com]]|last = Brownlee|first = Shannon|title = Swallowing Ephedra|url = http://www.salon.com/2000/06/07/ephedra/|date = 2000-06-07|accessdate = 2008-10-07}}</ref><ref name="little-pill">{{cite news |publisher = ''[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]''|title = Little Pill, Big Trouble|last = Crabtree|first = Penni|url = http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/business/20030720-9999_mz1b20metabo.html|date = 2003-07-20|accessdate = 2008-10-07}}</ref> Ellis and a boyhood friend, Michael Blevins, were arrested in 1989 for producing and distributing methamphetamine. Both Ellis and Blevins cooperated with federal authorities in return for lighter sentences. Following Blevins' release from prison, the two formed Metabolife to market ephedra, an herbal supplement containing compounds chemically related to methamphetamine.<ref name="little-pill"/> Ellis served as the company's CEO until September 2000, when he was succeeded by David Brown (Brown went on to serve as president and CEO of [[Protandim|LifeVantage]] in 2008).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=23461893&ticker=LFVN:US | title = Executive profile: David Brown | work = [[BusinessWeek]]}}</ref>
Metabolife 356, an ephedra supplement manufactured by [[Chemins]],<ref name=Record>{{cite news|last=Gonzalez |first=Steve |title=Metabolife and Walgreen's hit up for $450k |url=http://www.madisonrecord.com/news/133596-metabolife-and-walgreens-hit-up-for-450k |accessdate=2012-08-22 |newspaper=[[The Madison / St. Clair Record]] |date=November 30, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015181712/http://madisonrecord.com/news/133596-metabolife-and-walgreens-hit-up-for-450k |archivedate=October 15, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Bortnick>{{cite news|last=Bortnick|first=Barry|title=Diet drug maker faces wrongful death lawsuits -- maker of Metabolife 356 is targeted|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5948443.html|accessdate=2012-08-23|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Colorado Springs)|The Gazette]]|date=April 22, 2000}}</ref> was initially marketed by Metabolife as a [[bodybuilding supplement]], but in 1995 was rebranded as an aid for [[dieting]]. The product became highly successful due to a marketing plan that enlisted customers to advertise and sell the supplement;<ref name="salon"/> at their peak, sales of Metabolife 356 were in the hundreds of millions of dollars annually.<ref name="sdbj"/> At one point, Metabolife offered the [[Russia|Russian government]] $15 million to paint its logo on an [[International Space Station]] rocket and incorporate Metabolife's ephedra supplement into the diet of its [[cosmonaut]]s.<ref name="natural-causes">{{cite book | title = Natural Causes | first = Dan | last = Hurley | publisher = [[Broadway Books]] | year = 2006 | location = [[New York City|New York]] | isbn = 978-0-7679-2042-1}}</ref>
== Regulation and lobbying == In the late 1990s, the [[Food and Drug Administration|U.S. FDA]] considered regulating ephedra more strictly, in response to reports of adverse reactions and more than 100 deaths linked to the supplement.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wolfe SM |title=Medicine. Ephedra--scientific evidence versus money/politics |journal=Science |volume=300 |issue=5618 |pages=437 |date=April 2003 |pmid=12702860 |doi=10.1126/science.1081910}}</ref> These included reports of [[psychosis]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Verduin ML, Labbate LA |title=Psychosis and delirium following metabolife use |journal=Psychopharmacology bulletin |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=42–5 |year=2002 |pmid=12473963}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Walton R, Manos GH |title=Psychosis related to ephedra-containing herbal supplement use |journal=Southern Medical Journal |volume=96 |issue=7 |pages=718–20 |date=July 2003 |pmid=12940331 |doi=10.1097/01.SMJ.0000054913.04507.68}}</ref> [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Enders JM, Dobesh PP, Ellison JN |title=Acute myocardial infarction induced by ephedrine alkaloids |journal=Pharmacotherapy |volume=23 |issue=12 |pages=1645–51 |date=December 2003 |pmid=14695044 |doi=10.1592/phco.23.15.1645.31959}}</ref> [[stroke]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chen C, Biller J, Willing SJ, Lopez AM |title=Ischemic stroke after using over the counter products containing ephedra |journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences |volume=217 |issue=1 |pages=55–60 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14675610 |doi=10.1016/j.jns.2003.08.012}}</ref> and [[diabetic ketoacidosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Case CC, Maldonado M |title=Diabetic ketoacidosis associated with Metabolife: a report of two cases |journal=Diabetes, obesity & metabolism |volume=4 |issue=6 |pages=402–6 |date=November 2002 |pmid=12406039 |doi=10.1046/j.1463-1326.2002.00235.x}}</ref> A clinical trial conducted to address safety concerns found that Metabolife 365 increased [[blood pressure]] and induced mild [[cardiac arrhythmia]]s; the trial concluded that there were serious safety concerns associated with the use of Metabolife.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=McBride BF, Karapanos AK, Krudysz A, Kluger J, Coleman CI, White CM |title=Electrocardiographic and hemodynamic effects of a multicomponent dietary supplement containing ephedra and caffeine: a randomized controlled trial |journal=JAMA: the Journal of the American Medical Association |volume=291 |issue=2 |pages=216–21 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14722148 |doi=10.1001/jama.291.2.216 |url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/291/2/216}}</ref>
Metabolife took an active role in [[lobbying]] against regulation of ephedra, forming an advocacy group called the Dietary Supplement Safety and Science Coalition and contributing heavily to [[Congressman|Congressmen]] [[Brian Bilbray]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[California|Calif.]]) and [[Dan Burton]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Indiana|Ind.]]), among other politicians.<ref name="salon"/> Bilbray subsequently criticized the FDA's treatment of Metabolife and its efforts to regulate ephedra. During this period in the late 1990s, Metabolife contributed $1.6 million in [[soft money]] to both political parties, and almost $3 million to [[lobbyists]].<ref name="little-pill"/> At the state level, Metabolife contributed $10,000 to then-Governor of Texas [[George W. Bush]], who intervened to stop regulation which would have banned [[Over-the-counter drug|over-the-counter]] sales of ephedra. Bush subsequently returned the $10,000 after Ellis' and Blevins' methamphetamine convictions were publicized in the media.<ref name="little-pill"/> Other recipients of Metabolife contributions included then-Governor of California [[Gray Davis|Joseph Graham 'Gray' Davis, Jr.]], who was given $175,000.<ref name="little-pill"/>
== Legal issues == Metabolife was investigated by the [[Internal Revenue Service]] and the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] for [[income tax evasion]]; ultimately, the company pleaded guilty to filing fraudulent tax returns and was sentenced to pay a criminal fine of $600,000.<ref name="doj-1">{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/tax/usaopress/2005/txdv05cas51005_1.pdf |title=Metabolife and owner William Bradley Plead Guilty to Tax Charges |publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]] |date=2005-10-05 |accessdate=2008-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012223851/http://www.usdoj.gov/tax/usaopress/2005/txdv05cas51005_1.pdf |archivedate=2008-10-12 |df= }}</ref> Metabolife owner William Bradley also pleaded guilty to evading millions of dollars in taxes and was sentenced to 6 months in [[federal prison]] and 2 years of [[probation]].<ref name="doj-1"/><ref>{{cite news | url =http://www.sdreader.com/php/cityshow.php?id=1476 | title = Breaking Stories: Case Closed | last = Potter | first = Matt | publisher = SanDiegoReader.com | date = 2006-10-05 | accessdate = 2008-04-11}}</ref>
According to federal prosecutors in the case against Metabolife and its executives, the company’s certified public accountant, Michael Compton, knew about and helped conceal Metabolife’s illegal activities.<ref name=Crabtree/> Compton had admitted falsifying tax returns for company executives and was complicit in the company’s failure to account for $93.7 million in income on its income tax returns from 1996 through 1999.<ref name=Crabtree>{{cite web|last1=Crabtree|first1=Penni|title=Kickbacks also paid, affidavit alleges|url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/business/20031202-9999_1b2metabolif.html|publisher=[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015|date=December 2, 2003}}</ref><ref name=hettena>{{cite web|last1=Hettena|first1=Seth|title=Metabolife: its rise and fall|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20041017&slug=drugdiet17|publisher=[[Seattle Times]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015|date=October 17, 2004}}</ref><ref name=Bauder>{{cite web|last1=Bauder|first1=Don|title=A Metabolife Death|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2003/nov/26/metabolife-death/|publisher=[[San Diego Reader]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015|date=November 26, 2003}}</ref><ref name=Vardi>{{cite web|last1=Vardi|first1=Nathan|title=Poison Pills|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2004/0419/078.html|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=February 26, 2015|date=April 19, 2004}}</ref> Compton had assisted the company in setting up secret offshore bank accounts and trusts in the Cayman Islands and was aware that Bradley, Ellis, and Blevins each had over $1 million in unreported cash concealed in safes within their homes.<ref name=Bauder/> In July 2002, criminal investigators of the Internal Revenue Service raided Compton's office, seizing documents and computer data,<ref name=Bauder/> and in November 2003, 10 days after a warrant against Metabolife and its principals was unsealed in U.S. District Court, Compton died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head.<ref name=Bauder/>
Some of the politicians associated with Metabolife also encountered legal difficulties; Texas state legislators [[Jeff Wentworth]] and Rick Green were accused of illegal lobbying on behalf of the company.<ref name="little-pill"/>
Following the FDA's ban of ephedra, Michael Ellis was indicted on eight counts of [[making false statements]] to the FDA in an effort to obstruct regulation of ephedra.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2002-08-15-ephedra_x.htm | title = Criminal investigation sought for diet supplement seller | publisher = ''[[USA Today]]'' | date = 2002-08-15| accessdate = 2007-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/business/20050806-9999-1b6metabo.html | title = Metabolife will plead guilty, end tax probe | first = David | last = Washburn | publisher = ''[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' | date = 2005-08-06| accessdate = 2007-04-11}}</ref> Ellis ultimately [[guilty plea|pled guilty]] to a single count of lying to the FDA about the adverse effects of Metabolife 356. He was sentenced to 6 months in federal prison and a $20,000 fine.<ref name="sdbj-2">{{cite news|publisher = ''Law360'' | title = Metabolife Founder Gets 6-Month Prison Sentence | url = http://www.law360.com/articles/58799/metabolife-ceo-gets-6-months-for-misleading-fda }}</ref>
In response to falling sales, and facing more than $1 billion in [[personal injury]] legal claims related to Metabolife 356,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.redorbit.com/news/health/525451/exmetabolife_hopes_to_settle_ephedra_claims/index.html?source=r_health | title = Ex-Metabolife Hopes to Settle Ephedra Claims | first = Penni | last = Crabtree | publisher = ''[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' | date = 2002-06-02 | accessdate = 2007-04-11}}</ref> Metabolife filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] in 2005.<ref name="sdbj">{{cite news|url=http://www.sdbj.com/print.asp?aid=59191742.9909937.1211275.7239605.8672841.848&aID2=93166 |title=Metabolife Continues Its Search for Buyer |first=Mike |last=Allen |publisher=''San Diego Business Journal'' |date=2005-10-17 |accessdate=2007-04-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195909/http://www.sdbj.com/print.asp?aid=59191742.9909937.1211275.7239605.8672841.848&aID2=93166 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The company's furnishings and property, including a large collection of artwork, were liquidated in late 2006 to compensate creditors and settle outstanding personal-injury claims.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061130/news_7m30bell.html | title = Metabolife's Artwork Goes on the Block Today | first = Diane | last = Bell | publisher = ''San Diego Union-Tribune'' | date = 2006-11-30 | accessdate = 2007-06-22}}</ref>
Metabolife's non-ephedra assets were acquired by Ideasphere Inc., a New York-based dietary-supplement manufacturer, for $12 million in 2007.<ref name="sdbj-2"/> In 2008, Michael Ellis authored a memoir entitled ''The Metabolife Story: The Rape of Cinderella'', with a testimonial by the former [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] special agent who arrested Ellis in 1989 for producing and distributing methamphetamine.

{{wikisource|Order Establishing Combatant Status Review Tribunal}} {{wikisource|Combatant Status Review Tribunal (fact sheet of October 17, 2006)}} '''Military Police: Enemy Prisoners of War, Retained Personnel, Civilian Internees and Other Detainees''' is the full title of a [[United States Army]] regulation usually referred to as '''AR 190-8''', that lays out how the United States Army should treat captives.<ref name=DoDAr190-8-19971001> {{cite web | url=http://www.au.af.mil/au/awc/awcgate/law/ar190-8.pdf | title=Military Police: Enemy Prisoners of War, Retained Personnel, Civilian Internees and Other Detainees''' | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=October 1, 1997 | accessdate=June 8, 2007 }}</ref>
This document is notable as the [[United States Supreme Court]] advised the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], in its ruling on ''[[Hamdi v. Rumsfeld]]'' in 2004, that the [[Combatant Status Review Tribunal|Tribunals]] the DoD convened to review the status of the [[Guantanamo captive]]s should be modeled after the Tribunals described in AR-190-8.
==The authority of AR 190-8 Tribunals==
As a signatory to the [[Geneva Conventions]], the United States is obliged to convene a "[[competent tribunal]]" to determine the status of any captive "should any doubt arise" as to their proper status.<ref name=HumanRightsFirstAnalysisOfCSRT> {{cite web |url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/us_law/detainees/status_review_080204.htm |title=Human Rights First Analyzes DOD's Combatant Status Review Tribunals |publisher=[[Human Rights First]] |accessdate=June 8, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712195007/http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/us_law/detainees/status_review_080204.htm |archivedate=July 12, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
The [[Third Geneva Convention]] states that all captives must be accorded the protections of [[POW]] status until a competent tribunal convenes, and determines the captive does not qualify for such status.<ref name=DoDAr190-8-19971001/> *AR-190-8 Tribunals are authorized to confirm that a captive is a [[lawful enemy combatant|lawful combatant]], after all, who should continue to be detained as a prisoner of war until hostilities cease. *AR-190-8 Tribunals are authorized to determine that a captive is an innocent [[civilian]], who should be immediately released. *AR-190-8 Tribunals are authorized to confirm that a captive is a [[combatant]] who acted in a way that he or she should be stripped of POW status. According to the Geneva Conventions, only captives who have been stripped of POW status, by a competent tribunal, can face charges for [[war crimes]] they committed in situation of [[armed conflict]].
==Structure of AR-190-8 Tribunals and Combatant Status Review Tribunals compared==
{| class="wikitable" |- | '''AR-190-8 Tribunal''' || '''Combatant Status Review Tribunal''' |- | *Authorized to confirm that a captive is a lawful combatant. *Authorized to determine that a captive is an innocent civilian. *Authorized to determine that a combatant should be stripped of the protections of POW status, and can, subsequently, face war crime charges. || *Authorized to confirm or dispute earlier, secret determinations that captives are "[[enemy combatant]]s". *Explicitly not authorized to determine whether captives qualify for the protections of POW status. |- | *Three officers, presided by a [[field grade]] officer, make the determination, on the preponderance of the evidence. || *Three officers, [[Tribunal President (CSRT)|whose President]] is a [[field grade]] officer, make the determination, on the preponderance of the evidence. One of the officers must be a military lawyer. |- | * Another officer, who does not share in the determination, support the officers making the determination. He or she collates the information the Tribunal bases its decision on. It is preferred that this be a military lawyer. || * Two officers, who do not share in the determination, support the officers making the determination. **The [[Recorder (CSRT)|Recorder]] collates the information the Tribunal bases its decision on. The Recorders were military lawyers. **The [[Personal Representative (CSRT)|Personal Representative]] meets with the captive: ***explains the Tribunal's procedures; explained that participation was voluntary ***goes over the unclassified allegations against the captive, which they would be learning, for the first time; ***tries to get the captive to share their account of the incidents recorded in the allegations. ***determines whether the captive wanted to attend, submit a written statement, or allow the Tribunal to convene without their participation; ***if the captive doesn't attend, or is disruptive, and is removed, it is the Personal Representative's responsibility to present the captive's version of events. |}
==June 4, 2007 dismissal of charges against Guantanamo captives==
On June 4, 2007 Colonel [[Peter Brownback]] and Naval Captain [[Keith J. Allred]] dismissed all charges against Guantanamo captives [[Omar Khadr]] and [[Salim Ahmed Hamdan]], on jurisdictional grounds. They ruled that the [[Military Commissions Act of 2006]] had only authorized the [[Guantanamo military commission]]s to charge captives who were classified as "[[illegal enemy combatant]]s", and since Khadr and Hamdan's Combatant Status Review Tribunals had only made the determination that they were "[[enemy combatant]]s", their military commissions lacked the jurisdiction to hear the charges.
==See also== *[[Administrative Review Board]] *[[Enemy combatants]] *[[OARDEC]] *[[Unlawful enemy combatants]]

|footnotes = |chief3_name=|chief3_position=|chief4_name=|chief4_position=|chief5_name=|chief5_position=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} [[New Zealand]]'s '''Law Commission''' was established in 1986 by the Law Commission Act 1985.<ref>[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1985/0151/latest/DLM85586.html Establishment]. Law Commission Act 1985—Section 4. "For the purpose of this Act, there is hereby established a commission to be called the Law Commission."</ref><ref>[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1985/0151/latest/DLM85586.html Short Title and commencement]. Law Commission Act 1985—Section 1. "This Act shall come into force on 1 February 1986."</ref> The Commission is an independent [[Crown entity]] (ICE) as defined in the [[Crown Entities Act 2004]].<ref>[http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/APCITY/UNPAN022162.pdf Crown Entities Act 2004] p91</ref>
The main objective of the Law Commission, as declared in its founding legislation, is to monitor and [[Critical thinking|critically analyse]] the laws of New Zealand with a view to identifying—and proposing solutions to—their possible shortcomings.<ref>"[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1985/0151/latest/DLM87301.html Functions]". Law Commission Act 1985—Section 5. "The principal functions of the Commission are (...) to take and keep under review in a systematic way the law of New Zealand (...) to make recommendations for the reform and development of the law of New Zealand (...) to advise on the review of any aspect of the law of New Zealand conducted by any government department or organisation (...)."</ref>
The commission is part of the [[Commonwealth Association of Law Reform Agencies]].
The Law Commission reviews, reforms and develops New Zealand law. It then makes recommendations to Government to improve the law. It also advises its Responsible Minister and government agencies on how to make the law more accessible and easier to understand.
The Commission has a commitment to consult the public on areas of law that it reviews. It promotes discussion and consultation by publishing Issues Papers. It invites submissions from the public before it makes recommendations to the Responsible Minister. It publishes these recommendations in a report to Parliament. The Minister tables the report and the government then decides whether and how it will amend the law.
==Commissioners==
As of January 2018 the Law Commission comprises four members:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/content/our-people|title=Our people {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref>
*The Hon Sir Douglas White - President *Donna Buckingham *Helen McQueen *Belinda Clark QSO<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/belinda-clark|title=Belinda Clark appointed as Law Commissioner {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref>
==Projects==
The Commission's current projects (at May 2018) include:
*Review of Abortion Law Reform<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/abortion|title=Abortion Law Reform {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/abortion/|title=Abortion Law Reform|website=lawcom.govt.nz/abortion|language=en-NZ|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> *The Use of DNA in Criminal Investigations<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/our-projects/use-dna-criminal-investigations|title=The Use of DNA in Criminal Investigations {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dnareview.lawcom.govt.nz/|title=DNA and crime – Have your say on DNA|website=dnareview.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en-NZ|access-date=2018-01-31}}</ref> *Review of the [[Property (Relationships) Act 1976]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/our-projects/review-property-relationships-act-1976|title=Review of the Property (Relationships) Act 1976 {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://prareview.lawcom.govt.nz/|title=Reviewing the Property (Relationships) Act|website=Reviewing the Property (Relationships) Act|language=en-NZ|access-date=2018-01-31}}</ref> *Declaratory Judgments<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/our-projects/declaratory-judgments|title=Declaratory Judgments {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref> *Second Review of the [[Evidence Act 2006]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/our-projects/second-review-evidence-act-2006|title=Second Review of the Evidence Act 2006 {{!}} Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref>

[[Image:First Majlis MPs.jpg|right|250 px|thumb|Members of the First Majlis (October 7, 1906 — June 23, 1908). The central photograph is that of [[Morteza Gholi Khan Hedayat]], [[Sani-ol Douleh]], the first Chairman of the First Majlis. He had been for seven months the Finance Minister when he was assassinated on 6 February 1911 by two [[Georgian people|Georgian]] nationals in Tehran.[[Morgan Shuster|W. Morgan Shuster]], ''The Strangling of Persia'', 3rd printing (T. Fisher Unwin, London, 1913), pp. 48, 119, 179. According to Shuster (p. 48), "Five days later [measured from February 1st] the Persian Minister of Finance, [[Saniu'd-Dawleh]] was shot and killed in the streets of Teheran by two Georgians, who also succeeded in wounding four of the Persian police before they were captured. The Russian consular authorities promptly refused to allow these men to be tried by the Persian Government, and took them out of the country under Russian protection, claiming that they would be suitably punished."
See also: [[Mohammad-Reza Nazari]], ''The retreat by the Parliament in overseeing the financial matters is a retreat of democracy'', in Persian, Mardom-Salari, No. 1734, 20 Bahman 1386 [[Iranian calendar|AH]] (9 February 2008), {{cite web |url=http://www.mardomsalari.com/template1/News.aspx?NID=20301 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427045644/http://www.mardomsalari.com/template1/News.aspx?NID=20301 |archivedate=2009-04-27 |df= }}.]] [[Image:National Guards of Tehran.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Three ''National Soldiers of [[Tehran]]''. A postcard of the period. The text in the heading reads: ''May the National Consultative Assembly [Majles-e Shoura-ye Melli] be everlasting and long live National Soldiers!'' The text in the middle of the photograph reads: ''National Soldiers of Tehran''.]] The '''Persia Constitution of 1906'''Tilmann J. Röder, The Separation of Powers: Historical and Comparative Perspectives, in: Rainer Grote and Tilmann J. Röder, Constitutionalism in Islamic Countries (Oxford University Press 2012), p. 321-3372. The article includes scientific English translation of the following documents: The Fundamental Law (Qanun-e Asasi-e Mashruteh) of the Iranian Empire of December 30, 1906 (p. 359-365); The Amendment of the Fundamental Law of the Iranian Empire of October 7, 1907 (p. 365-372). * The Mashruteh Constitution of Iran (farsi). Berlin 2014. {{ISBN|9783844292923}}. [http://www.epubli.de/shop/buch/The-Mashruteh-Constitution-of-Iran-mashruteh-org-9783844292923/37290 (Details)][http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c109:H.+Res.+942: Recognizing the centennial anniversary] 109th CONGRESS, 2d Session, H. RES. 942, 25 July 2006 ({{lang-fa|قانون اساسی مشروطه 1906}}), was the first constitution of Persia ([[Iran]]) that resulted from the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] and it was written by [[Hassan Pirnia]], [[Hossein Pirnia]], and [[Ismail Mumtaz]], among others.For a modern English translation of the constitution and related laws see, Tilmann J. Röder, The Separation of Powers: Historical and Comparative Perspectives, in: Grote/Röder, Constitutionalism in Islamic Countries (Oxford University Press 2011). It divides into five chapters with many articles that developed over several years. The [[Constitution of Belgium|Belgian constitution]], like the constitutions of other European states, served as a partial model for the Iranian constitution.{{cite encyclopedia |last= Destrée |first=Annette | title= BELGIAN-IRANIAN RELATIONS | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2015-08-21|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/belgian-iranian-relations}} ==The electoral and fundamental laws of 1906== The electoral and fundamental laws of 1906 established the [[electoral system]] and the internal frameworks of the [[Majlis of Iran|Majlis]] (Parliament) and the Senate. By the royal proclamation of August 5, 1906, [[Mozzafar al-Din Shah]] created this first constitution "for the peace and tranquility of all the people of Persia." [[Muhammad Ali Shah Qajar]] is credited with chapters 4 and 5. ===The electoral law of September 9, 1906=== The electoral law of September 9, 1906 defined the regulations for the Elections to the Majlis. ====Disenfranchised==== Article 3 of this chapter stated that (1) women, (2) foreigners, (3) those under 25, (4) "persons notorious for mischievous opinions," (5) those with a criminal record, (6) active military personnel, and a few other groups are not permitted to vote. ====Election qualifications==== Article 4 stated that the elected must be (1) fully literate in [[Persian language|Persian]], (2) "they must be Iranian subjects of Iranian extraction," (3) "be locally known," (4) "not be in government employment," (5) be between 30 and 70 years old, and (6) "have some insight into affairs of State." Article 7 asserted, "Each elector has one vote and can only vote in one [social] class." ===The fundamental laws of December 30, 1906=== The fundamental laws of December 30, 1906 defined the role of the Majlis in the system and its framework. It further defined a [[bicameral legislature]]. Article 1 established the [[Majles|National Consultative Assembly]]This became known as the [[Majles|Islamic Consultative Assembly]] after the [[Islamic Revolution]]. based "on justice." Article 43 stated, "There shall be constituted another Assembly, entitled the [[Senate of Iran|Senate]]." ==The supplementary fundamental laws of October 7, 1907== {{Over-quotation|section|date=November 2013}} The supplementary fundamental laws of October 7, 1907 established the charter of [[human rights|rights]] and overall [[Form of government|system of governance]]. The Supplementary Fundamental Laws of October 7, 1907 consist of ten sections:{{cite web|url=http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution |title=Iran's 1906 Constitution |publisher=[[Foundation for Iranian Studies]] |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}} 1. General Dispositions 2. Rights of the Persian Nation 3. Powers of the Realm 4. Rights of Members of the Assembly 5. Rights of Persian Throne 6. Concerning the Ministers 7. Powers of the Tribunal of Justice 8. Provincial and Departmental Councils (anjumans) 9. Concerning the Finances 10. The Army The original Fundamental Law, containing 51 Articles, was promulgated on Dhu’l-Qu’da 14, A.H. 1324 (December 30, 1906) by Muzaffaru’d-Din Shah, who died just 4 days later. The following supplementary laws were ratified by his son and successor Shah Muhammad ‘Ali on Sha’ban 29, A.H. 1325 (October 7, 1907) ===General Dispositions=== Article 1 and 2 of the laws, established [[Islam]] as the official religion of Persia/Iran, and specified that all laws of the nation must be approved by a committee of Shi'a clerics. Later, these two articles were mainly ignored by the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Pahlavis]], which sometimes resulted in anger and uprising of clerics and religious masses: (See: [[Islamic revolution#Pahlavi dynasty and anti-Islamic policy|Pahlavis and non-Islamic policies]]) Articles 3-7 under the General Dispositions discuss the logistics of borders, flag specifications and Tehran as the capital of the country. They also elaborate on the property rights of foreign nationals in Iran as well as the inability to suspend the principles of the constitution.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Rights of the Persian Nation=== In the "Rights of the Persian Nation," articles 8-25 discuss an array of rights inherent to all citizens of Iran. These rights include personal and property rights as well as freedom of expression and censorship. They briefly touch on the rights of citizenship and to move freely within the country.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Powers of the Realm=== This section of the Supplementary Fundamental Laws of October 7, 1907 begins by stating the following: {{cquote|The powers of the realm are all derived from the people; and the Fundamental Law regulates the employment of those powers.}} Article 27 discussed the three categories that the power of the realm is divided into as: {{cquote| First, the legislative power which is specially concerned with the making or amelioration of laws. This power is derived from His Imperial Majesty, the National Consultative Assembly, and the Senate, of which three sources each has the right to introduce laws, provided that the continuance thereof be dependent on their not being at variance with the standards of the ecclesiastical law, and on its approval by the Members of the two Assemblies, and the Royal ratification. The enacting and approval of laws connected with the revenue and expenditure of the kingdom are, however, specially assigned to the National Consultative Assembly. The explanation and interpretation of the laws are, moreover, amongst the special functions of the above-mentioned assembly. Second, the judicial power, by which is meant the determining of rights. This power belongs exclusively to the ecclesiastical tribunals in matters connected with the ecclesiastical law, and to the civil tribunals in matters connected with ordinary law. Third, the executive power, which appertains to the King, that is to say, the laws and ordinances are carried out by the Ministers and State officials in the august name of His Imperial Majesty in such manner as the Law Defines.}} The remaining articles entail a permanent distinction between the three powers as well as their relativity in each province, department and district.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Rights of Members of the Assembly=== This section includes the roles of the National Consultative Assembly and the Senate and the stipulations for membership within the two branches of government.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Rights of the Persian Throne=== In the Rights of the Persian Throne, the section begins with several articles outlining the duties of the Shah and the logistics of the throne. These include the process of succession to the throne, ascending to the throne and how to deal with instances issues like death. It further discusses the duties of the Shah like the appointment and dismissal of Ministers and The granting of military rank, decoration and other honorary distinctions. The shah also commands the military and has the final say on whether or not to wage war. This sections concludes in Article 57 by underlining the precise degree of power that the Shah obtains saying: {{cquote|. The Royal prerogatives and powers are only those explicitly mentioned in the present Constitutional Law.}}http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Concerning the Ministers=== Articles 58-70 comment on the duties and laws regarding the Ministers. This section also helps to establish the specific roles that Ministers play in the government. Several articles talk specifically about how Ministers are appointed as well as how they are held accountable for their delinquencies. ===Powers of the Tribunal of Justice=== This section begins by stating the purpose for the Ministry of Justice with article 71: {{cquote| *ART. 71. **The Supreme Ministry of Justice and the judicial tribunals are the places officially destine for the redress of public grievances, while judgement in all matters falling within the scope of the Ecclesiastical Law is vested in just mujtahids possessing the necessary qualifications.}} Articles 72-82 continue on to discuss the instructions for dealing with public disputes and inquiries as well as the legal aspects of carrying out justice in regards to law violations. Several articles explain the rules for all proceedings of tribunals declaring that they must be public and that all decisions must be based on reason and supported by proof in accordance to the law. In articles 83-89, the issue of appointment is addressed and explained in regards to the Public Prosecutor and the members of the judicial tribunals, corroborating with the laws set forth.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Provincial and Departmental Councils (anjumans)=== The various Provincial and Departmental Councils are discussed in this section, establishing the special regulations for the different branches. The fundamental laws regulating these assemblies includes the election of the members of the provincial and departmental councils, the supervision over all reforms connected with the public advantage, and duties of the expenditure for the individual councils.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===Concerning the Finances=== The regulations and management of finances is provided in articles 94-103. These articles include laws regarding taxes, tax exemptions, the set laws regarding the approval of the budget as well as the role of the Financial Commission. The Financial Commission's role is: {{cquote|to inspect and analyse the accounts of the Department of Finance and to liquidate the accounts of all debtors and creditors of the Treasury.}} The section concludes with the idea that the institution and organization of the Financial Commission must be in accordance with the Law.http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution ===The Army=== The last section of the Supplementary Fundamental Laws of October 7, 1907 is the Army. This sections outlines all elements of recruitment of troops, the duties and rights of the military, and the promotion of military personnel. It further discusses the budget of the military which is determined by the National Consultative Assembly each year, and rights regarding military personnel. The Supplementary Fundamental Laws of October 7, 1907 conclude with the following statements:http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution "In the Name of God, blessed and exalted is He." "The complementary provisions of the Fundamental Code of Laws have been perused and are correct. Please God, our Royal Person will observe and regard all of them. Our sons and successors also will, please God, confirm these sacred laws and principles. The Law only says that the laws mustn't be against Islam, but not that the laws have to be Islamic. Laws can indeed be un-Islamic and not be at variance with any specified Islamic law. The Constitutional Revolution had a role in suppressing the power that the clergy and the religion had. The Revolution gave rights to minorities such as [[Zoroastrian]]s, Christians and Jews.{{cite web|url=http://www.gozaar.org/template1.php?id=425&language=english |accessdate=October 13, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024144423/http://www.gozaar.org/template1.php?id=425 |archivedate=October 24, 2007 }} ==See also== {{wikisource}} * [[Attempts at Constitutionalization in Iran]] * [[Iran Constituent Assembly, 1949]] * [[Iranian constitutional referendum, 1963]] * [[Constitution of Islamic Republic of Iran]] ==References and notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Majlis}} * [http://fis-iran.org/en/resources/legaldoc/iranconstitution Iran's 1906 Constitution and Its Supplement] * [http://mashruteh.org/wiki/index.php?title=%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%88%D9%86_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B3%DB%8C_%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B7%D9%87 Constitution of Iran, 1906 (farsi)] * [http://www.iranchamber.com/history/constitutional_revolution/constitutional_revolution.php Constitutional Revolution] from ''Iran Chamber Society'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Persian Constitution Of 1906}} [[Category:Persian Constitutional Revolution]] [[Category:Defunct constitutions]] [[Category:Legal history of Iran|Constitution, 1906]] [[Category:Politics of Qajar Iran]] [[Category:1906 in Iran]] [[Category:1906 in law]] [[Category:20th century in Iran|Constitution, 1906]] [[Category:1906 documents]] [[Category:Constitutions of Iran]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox law firm | name = Pinsent Masons | logo = [[Image:Pinsent Masons logo.png]] | headquarters = Crown Place
[[London]], {{postcode|EC|2}}
[[United Kingdom]] | num_offices = 24 offices in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Falkland Islands]] and 10 other countries | num_attorneys = | num_lawyers = | num_employees = 2500+ | practice_areas = | key_people = | revenue = [[Pound sterling|£]]432.1 million (2016/17)https://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/blogs/financials-2017-pinsents-breaks-400m-barrier-to-post-double-digit-pep-growth-in-strong-year/ | profit_per_equity_partner = | date_founded = 1769 | founder = | company_type = [[Limited liability partnership]] | slogan = | homepage = {{URL|https://www.pinsentmasons.com}} | dissolved = }} '''Pinsent Masons LLP''' is an international [[law firm]] which specialises in the energy, infrastructure, financial services, real estate and advanced manufacturing and technology sectors.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online-july-2016/pinsents-sees-slowdown-in-growth-as-turnover-up-5-5-to-382m/|title=Pinsents sees slowdown in growth as turnover up 5.5% to £382m {{!}} The Lawyer {{!}} Legal News and Jobs {{!}} Advancing the business of law|website=www.thelawyer.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} The firm ranks among the top hundred law firms in the world by turnover.{{Cite web|url=https://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/analysis/global-100-2017/the-global-100-the-main-table/|title=Global 100 2017 - Main Table {{!}} www.legalbusiness.co.uk|last=Business|first=Legal|website=www.legalbusiness.co.uk|access-date=2016-07-11}} Pinsent Masons LLP has over 400 partners, a total legal team of around 1,800 people and more than 2,500 staff. More than 500 of the firm's staff are based in its international headquarters in the City of London. It has more PLC clients than any law firm except one.{{Cite web|url=http://adviser-rankings.com/law-firms-top-rankings|title=Law firms top rankings - Adviser Rankings Limited|website=adviser-rankings.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} Pinsent Masons was named 'Law Firm of the Year' in 2016 by respected industry magazine ''[[Legal Business]]''{{Cite web|url=http://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/index.php/awards-2015-menu/218-legal-business-awards-2016/5995-legal-business-awards-2015-winners|title=2016 Winners {{!}} www.legalbusiness.co.uk|last=Business|first=Legal|website=www.legalbusiness.co.uk|access-date=2016-07-11}} and 'Law Firm of the Year' 2016 at the ''Legal Week British Legal Awards''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.legalweek.com/sites/legalweek/2016/12/15/british-legal-awards-law-firm-of-the-year-pinsent-masons/?slreturn=20170109034042|title=British Legal Awards Law Firm of the Year: Pinsent Masons|website=LegalWeek.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}} In 2015 it was named 'The Most Innovative Law Firm in Europe' by the ''[[Financial Times]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://live.ft.com/Events/2015/FT-Innovative-Lawyers-Awards-Europe-2015|title=FT Innovative Lawyers Awards Europe 2015 organised by FT Live|website=FT Live|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-11}} The firm has 24 offices across Africa, Asia Pacific, Europe and the Middle East. In 2017, Pinsent Masons entered into an association with Saudi-based law firm AlSabhan & Alajaji.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pinsentmasons.com/en/locations/|title=Global Reach|website=www.pinsentmasons.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} ==History== Pinsent Masons has roots dating back to 1769. The modern day firm is the product of a series of mergers between firms including Pinsent & Co, Masons, Simpson Curtis, Biddle & Co, L'Estrange & Brett and McGrigors. Alumni of the legacy firms include former British Chancellor [[Alistair Darling]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/nobody-s-darling-1-508687|title=Nobody's Darling|website=www.scotsman.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} The firm's recent history has been dominated by a process of internationalisation. Over the past decade it has developed a presence in key major cities around the world: [[Beijing]] (2007), [[Singapore]] (2009), [[Paris]] (2012), [[Munich]] (2012), [[Brussels]] (2015), [[Sydney]] (2015), [[Melbourne]] (2015), [[Düsseldorf]] (2016), [[Johannesburg]] (2016), [[Madrid]] (2017), [[Dublin]] (2017)and [[Perth]] (2017).{{citenews|title=Pinsent Masons to open first African office|url=http://www.africanlawbusiness.com/news/6591-pinsent-masons-to-open-first-african-office|publisher=African Law & Business|date=2 August 2016}} The firm's board is led by Senior Partner Richard Foley and Managing Partner John Cleland. In 2016 the firm announced the appointment of former Secretary of State for International Development [[Douglas Alexander]] as a strategic adviser,{{citenews|title=Former Labour MP Douglas Alexander joins Pinsent Masons as 'strategic advisor'|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/business/professionals/former-labour-mp-douglas-alexander-7469132|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=1 March 2016}} and appointed its first external board member in the form of former banker Pauline Egan.{{citenews|title=Blog: Revolving doors: Pinsent Masons makes board appointments as BLP and Mayer Brown make City hires|url=http://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/index.php/lb-blog-view/6071-revolving-doors-pinsent-masons-makes-board-appointments-as-blp-and-mayer-brown-makes-city-hires|first=Madeleine|last=Farman|date=18 April 2016|publisher=legalbusiness.co.uk}} == Strategy == Unlike many firms of its size, the firm professes to specialise in only five global sectors: financial services, advanced manufacturing and technology, energy, real estate and infrastructure.{{Cite web|url=http://www.legalweek.com/legal-week/news/2364469/richard-foley-leadership-changes-wont-shift-sector-focus-at-pinsent-masons|title=Richard Foley: leadership changes won't shift sector focus at Pinsent Masons|website=LegalWeek.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} In FY2015/16 each of the sectors accounted for 20% of the firm's turnover, except for the energy and real estate sectors which accounted for 12% each. == Innovation == Pinsent Masons has won numerous awards for innovation[https://www.innovative.legal/awards/] In 2012 it was in the vanguard of firms to launch a contract lawyer service, called [https://www.pinsentmasonsvario.com/ Vario].http://www.managingpartner.com/news/business-strategy/pinsent-masons-launch-freelance-lawyer-service It also secured mandates to act as 'sole adviser' to corporates including [[Balfour Beatty]]http://www.balfourbeatty.com/news/balfour-beatty-appoints-pinsent-masons-as-sole-advisor-on-retained-work/?year=all&parentId=1212 and [[E.ON]].{{citenews|title=Pinsent Masons beats 40 firms to win sole legal provider contract for Eon|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online-october-2013/pinsent-masons-beats-40-firms-to-win-sole-legal-provider-contract-for-eon/|work=[[The Lawyer]]|date=3 October 2013|first= Kate |last=Beioley}} In 2015 the firm acquired the majority stake in [http://www.cericosolutions.com/ Cerico], an online compliance solutions business.{{citenews|title=Pinsent Masons' Richard Masters: Our tech product Cerico is taking on the world|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online-october-2013/pinsent-masons-beats-40-firms-to-win-sole-legal-provider-contract-for-eon/|work=[[The Lawyer]]|date=18 September 2015|first=Jonathon|last=Manning}} The firm also owns and operates [https://www.out-law.com/ Out-Law.com], a news service aimed at those with an interest in legal and commercial developments. == Diversity == Pinsent Masons is the highest ranked professional services firm in the Stonewall Workplace Equality Index.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pinsentmasons.com/en/media/press-releases/2016/pinsent-masons-recognised-among-top-five-inclusive-employers-in-stonewall-index/|title=Pinsent Masons recognised among top five inclusive employers in Stonewall Index|website=www.pinsentmasons.com|access-date=2016-07-11}} It is also ranked among ''The Times'' Top 50 Workplaces for Women 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://gender.bitc.org.uk/TTT502016|title=The Times Top 50 Employers for Women 2016|access-date=2016-07-11}} David Isaac, a partner of the firm, was appointed as Chair of the UK Equality and Human Rights Committee in 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/apr/01/nicky-morgan-under-fire-for-choosing-city-lawyer-to-head-equality-body|title=Nicky Morgan under fire for choosing City lawyer to head equality body|last=Asthana|first=Anushka|date=2016-04-01|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-07-11}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox court case | name=Polyukhovich v Commonwealth | court=[[High Court of Australia]] | image=Coat of Arms of Australia.svg | date decided=14 August 1992 | full name= Polyukhovich v The Commonwealth of Australia and Another | citations=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1991/32.html (1991) 172 CLR 501], [1991] HCA 32 | judges=[[Anthony Mason (judge)|Mason]] CJ, [[Gerard Brennan|Brennan]], [[William Deane|Deane]], [[Daryl Dawson|Dawson]], [[John Toohey (judge)|Toohey]], [[Mary Gaudron|Gaudron]] & [[Michael McHugh (judge)|McHugh]] JJ | prior actions=''Polyukhovich v The Commonwealth (1990) 95 ALR 502'' - injunction action | subsequent actions=none | opinions= '''(6:1)''' Section 9 of the ''War Crimes Act 1945'' (Cth) was valid as a law with respect to external affairs.<small> (per Mason CJ, Deane, Dawson, Toohey, Gaudron & McHugh JJ; Brennan J dissenting)</small>
'''(4:2)''' The statute did not invalidly usurp the judicial power of the Commonwealth. <small> (per Mason CJ, Dawson, Toohey & McHugh JJ; Deane & Gaudron JJ dissenting; Brennan J not deciding)</small>}}
'''''Polyukovich v The Commonwealth''''' [1991] HCA 32; (1991) 172 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 501, commonly referred to as the '''''War Crimes Act Case''''', was a significant case decided in the [[High Court of Australia]] regarding the scope of the external affairs power in [[section 51(xxix) of the Constitution of Australia|section 51(xxix) of the Constitution]] and the judicial power of the [[The Commonwealth of Australia|Commonwealth]].
==Background== The [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/wca1945121/ ''War Crimes Act 1945'' (Cth)] provided that any person who committed a war crime between 1 September 1939 and 8 May 1945 was guilty of an [[indictable offence]]. [[Ivan Polyukhovich|Ivan Timofeyevich Polyukhovich]] had been charged under the Act with war crimes, alleged to have been committed between September 1942 and May 1943 in the [[Ukraine]] while it was under German occupation in [[World War II]].
Polyukhovich's lawyers argued that the law was beyond the scope of Commonwealth legislative power in section 51(vi) (defence) and section 51(xxix) (external affairs) of the Constitution. He further argued that the attempt to make past criminal conduct an offence was an invalid attempt to usurp the judicial power of the Commonwealth, that power being vested by the Constitution in Chapter III courts, by enacting what was effectively a [[bill of attainder]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
==Decision==
===External affairs power=== By a majority of 6 to 1 (Brennan J dissenting) the court held that the Act was a valid exercise of the external affairs power. The six majority judges all wrote separate opinions. Mason CJ, Deane, Dawson, Gaudron & McHugh JJ were all of the opinion that as the subject matter of the legislation was external to Australia then the law was a valid one under the external affairs power. Mason CJ also said that if the Parliament considered that Australia had an interest or concern it was not for the court to examine whether there was a relevant interest or concern.
Toohey J, however, considered that it was not sufficient that the Act dealt with matters outside Australia. In his opinion, the subject matter had to 'touch and concern' Australia, In the event, he found that there was a sufficient connection between the subject matter of the Act and Australia to allow the law under section 51(xxix).
In dissent, Brennan J suggested that there must be a nexus between Australia and the 'external affair' involved. He held that, because the subject of war crimes in World War II was not an external affair at the time, i.e., 1939 to 1945, the subsequent acquisition of citizenship or residence in Australia by an individual was not enough to transform the subject matter into an external affair.
===Judicial power=== In relation to Polyukhovich's contention that the Act purported to usurp the judicial power of the Chapter III courts, the court held by a majority of 4 to 2 (Brennan J not deciding) that the statute did not invalidly usurp the judicial power of the Commonwealth. While the majority all accepted that a bill of attainder would offend the Commonwealth [[separation of powers]], the fact that a law operated ''[[Ex post facto law|ex post facto]]'' did not automatically make the law a bill of attainder. In addition, an ''ex post facto'' law of the kind under consideration was not a usurpation of judicial power.
==References== *{{cite book |last2=Williams|first2=George|authorlink= |last3=Brennan|first3=Sean|last=Blackshield|first=Anthony|title=Blackshield and Williams Australian Constitutional Law and Theory |year=2014 |edition=6 |publisher=Federation Press |location=Leichhardt, NSW |isbn=978-1-86287-918-8 |pages=607–614, 898–900 }}
==External links== *[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1991/32.html Text of the decision]
==See also== *[[List of High Court of Australia cases]]
